page.name: audit_guide
page.p: This guide outlines a step-by-step process for planning, performing, and reporting on an audit. It covers client acceptance/continuance, risk assessment, audit sampling, misstatement evaluation, and final reporting to stay compliant with International Standards on Auditing (ISAs).

tr.td: Evaluate client risk, independence, and ethical considerations before engagement; decide on acceptance or continuance.
Planning and Identifying the Risk of Misstatements
Assess risk of material misstatement at financial statement and assertion levels; determine materiality and sampling approach.
Selecting the Sample and Performing Substantive Testing
Determine sample size, select sampling method, and perform substantive audit procedures.
Classify misstatements, compare against thresholds, and schedule additional testing if required.
Determining the Impact on the Audit
Reassess risks, extend samples or apply alternative procedures, and modify the opinion if needed.
Communicate misstatements, evaluate responses, and assess uncorrected errors.
Documenting Audit Findings and Extrapolating Misstatements
Calculate projected misstatements, determine if thresholds are exceeded, and plan additional work.
Report uncorrected misstatements, assess pervasiveness, and prepare the final audit report.

page.p: Standards: ISA 210, ISA 220, and firm policy.
Pre-engagement evaluation: Assess integrity, reputation, and financial viability; evaluate conflicts, independence, and ethics; document rationale.
Decision-making: Decline engagements with unacceptable risk or independence concerns; if accepted, confirm scope and responsibilities in writing.
page.h3: 2. Planning and Identifying the Risk of Misstatements

ul.li: Risk assessment: Evaluate financial statement level risks (e.g., financial distress) and assertion level risks (e.g., complex valuations).
Materiality: Set overall materiality (e.g., 5-10% PBT or 1-2% revenue) and performance materiality (roughly 50-75% of overall materiality).
Sampling approach: Define statistical, non-statistical, monetary unit, or stratified sampling based on assessed risk.

page.h3: 3. Selecting the Sample and Performing Substantive Testing
page.p: Sample size guidance: apply adjustment factors of 0.5-0.7 (low RoMM), 0.8-1.0 (moderate RoMM), or 1.2-1.5 (high RoMM).

Sampling methods: statistical (random or systematic), non-statistical, monetary unit sampling, or stratified sampling. Perform inspection, recalculation, reperformance, or confirmation on selected items.

pre.code: Sample size (n) = (Z^2 * P * (1 - P)) / E^2 Where Z = confidence z-score, P = expected misstatement proportion, E = tolerable error rate

ul.li: Factual: objective errors such as calculation mistakes.
Judgmental: differences in estimates or assumptions.

page.p: Compare misstatements with overall and performance materiality as well as the acceptable misstatement performance threshold (AMPT). Request management adjustments when thresholds are exceeded.

tr.td: Objective errors such as calculation mistakes.
Compare with AMPT and overall materiality.
Verify corrections; escalate disagreements to governance.
Compare with performance materiality and judgment thresholds.
Challenge assumptions, seek evidence or experts.
Assess reasonableness; consider opinion modification if unresolved.
Compare projected error with materiality and extrapolation impact.
Document response; reassess sample strategy if management declines adjustments.

page.h3: 5. Determining the Impact on the Audit
page.p: Reassess risks, extend samples, apply alternative procedures, and document rationale for adjustments. Communicate key findings to governance.
Report misstatements, document discussions, verify corrections, and evaluate cumulative unadjusted errors for potential opinion modifications.
page.h3: 7. Documenting Audit Findings and Extrapolating Misstatements

pre.code: Projected (value-based) = Factual error * Total population value / Sample value Projected (unit-based) = Factual error * Total sampling units / Sample size

page.p: Use the larger projection; if it exceeds 50% of performance materiality, plan additional procedures. Record calculations and rationale.

Report uncorrected misstatements, assess pervasiveness, and determine the appropriate opinion (qualified, adverse, or modified). Ensure the final report reflects all significant findings and recommendations.

Following this guide ensures robust client evaluation, thorough planning, effective sampling, careful evaluation of misstatements, transparent communication, and accurate ISA-compliant reporting throughout the audit lifecycle.
